Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: In Search of the Greatest Good with Imperfect Triage in the Aftermath of Mass-Casualty Events

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this collaborative research project is to use mathematical models to investigate if and when triage is useful in the aftermath of mass-casualty incidents. The first stage of the project will develop and analyze mathematical models to identify conditions under which triage is most or least useful given that triage takes time and resources, and is imperfect. The second stage will focus on understanding the effects of triage errors on the expected number of survivors. In particular, the project will examine whether overtriage can be useful as suggested by some in the emergency medicine literature. The research will investigate the effective management of triage errors given that some degree of error is inevitable. Finally, in the third stage, a realistic simulation study will be carried out to test the basic principles and policies obtained in the first two stages.

This research project will contribute directly to the society's continuing efforts in improving emergency response systems. Mass-casualty incidents overwhelm the emergency response resources of a community and triage is the means by which these resources are rationed. However, potential benefits of patient triage are unclear mainly for two reasons. First, triage takes time and resources, which can be otherwise used, for example, for stabilizing patients. Second, triage decisions are highly error-prone with a significant overtriage rate. Although these problems have been recognized before, there has been no systematic effort to investigate whether triage meets its intended goals. The current practice largely relies on the belief that triage must have some benefits. The objective of this research is to question this belief and in doing that identify conditions under which triage is useful/harmful, when it makes sense to eliminate triage and move directly to treatment or transportation, and investigate the effects of triage errors.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Mass-casualty incidents such as terrorist bombings and major traffic accidents typically overwhelm the emergency response resources of a community. This necessitates rationing of these resources by triage, the practice of prioritizing patients according the urgency of their conditions, with the utilitarian goal of “doing the greatest good for the greatest number.” The rationale behind triage sounds perfectly reasonable. Why would one want to allocate resources to non-urgent cases when there are patients whose lives are at risk if they are not attended to within   short period of time? There are two reasons why the answer is not immediately clear. First, even though it is easy to identify patients with minor injuries, identification of truly urgent patients among those with more serious injuries is not an easy task, which means it does take some time and resources to classify patients, which can instead be used in the treatment of the patients. Second, studies show that triage decisions are highly error-prone with significant percentage of patients being classified as “immediate” even though they are not. As it is also frequently discussed in the emergency medicine literature, there has been no systematic effort in determining the benefits of triage. Thus, the current practice largely relies on the belief that triage must be beneficial. One of the main outcomes of this research project was identification of conditions under which triage is more useful. Based on a mathematical model, we found that the decision of whether to do or skip triage should be based on (i) the number of patients who need treatment; (ii) mean time it takes to triage and also treat patients with different urgency levels; and (iii) survival probability of each patient as a function of time. In particular, we found that when the number of patients is high, triage should be done; however, as the number of patients decreases with time, it is better to skip triage and directly treat or transport the patients. Our mathematical model provides an approximation for the threshold for the number of patients below which triage should be skipped. We find that this approximation works well using a simulation under more realistic settings than our mathematical model.

 

Intellectual merits: Despite the importance of mass-casualty triage and prioritization decisions, as it is frequently mentioned in the emergency medicine literature, there has not been any attempt to investigate whether the adopted triage policies work as intended. Since experimentation is not an option, the only way to investigate this question and gain some insights is through mathematical and simulation analysis. Thus, this project has been an important first step in understanding and assessing the usefulness of mass-casualty triage, how it depends on the size of the event and classification errors. It contributed in furthering our efforts in bringing an analytical perspective to the improvement of emergency response operations in mass-casualty events. Moreover, the analysis of the problems that are described in this proposal required the development of optimal scheduling policies for a class of queueing systems, which have not received any attention from the O.R. community. Therefore, our analysis directly contributed to this area within the optimal control of stochastic systems.
